Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the time blinking back at me. My mentor’s office hours were about to start, and I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss this chance. He’d made it clear—respect his time, don’t be late, don’t reschedule. I owed him that much, after all he’d invested in me. But as I slipped on my shoes, a message came from the mosque: a large crowd had gathered for a special remembrance, and the usual imam was away. No one else was authorized to lead. The community was waiting, expecting me to step forward, to guide them in prayer, to be present for them in this moment. My heart pounded. I could picture my mentor, waiting in his office, perhaps checking his watch, maybe even disappointed. At the same time, I could feel the weight of the congregation’s silent hope, their trust in me as their imam. I stood in the hallway, torn, the expectations of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore.
